item.title: 7. Family Influences
item.description:
I. Overview
This document summarizes findings from five research articles focusing on various aspects of adolescent development, with an emphasis on the role of family dynamics, cultural factors, and individual experiences in shaping adolescent well-being. The themes covered include:

The impact of adolescent secrecy and disclosure on adjustment.
Parental strategies for gaining knowledge about their adolescents' lives and the influence of these strategies on adolescent outcomes.
The interplay of cultural and general stressors on Latinx adolescents' mental health and the protective role of familismo.
The importance of family acceptance for the mental and physical health of LGBT adolescents.
II. Key Themes and Findings
A. Secrecy vs. Disclosure in Adolescent-Parent Relationships (Frijns et al., 2010)

Core Argument: The traditional measure of adolescent disclosure to parents conflates two distinct constructs: disclosure (what adolescents freely share) and secrecy (what adolescents actively conceal). Secrecy has a stronger impact on adolescent adjustment than previously recognized.
Key Findings:Factor analysis confirmed that disclosure and secrecy are separate constructs.
"Only secrecy was a longitudinal predictor of adolescent internalizing (i.e., depression)..."
Secrecy and delinquency were reciprocally related over time.
Increased secrecy is linked to "stress-related psychological problems, prevent full processing of the secret information, and cause mental rumination and obsessive preoccupation with the secret."
Implications: Researchers should distinguish between disclosure and secrecy when studying adolescent-parent relationships. Interventions should address the underlying reasons for adolescent secrecy.
B. Parental Knowledge and Strategies (Liu et al., 2020)

Core Argument: Parental knowledge of adolescent activities is influenced by both parent-driven strategies (e.g., solicitation, control, warmth) and child-driven strategies (e.g., disclosure).
Key Findings:Children's disclosure is the strongest predictor of parental knowledge compared to parental solicitation, behavioral control, and psychological control. The meta-analysis showed a significant correlation between children's disclosure and parental knowledge (ρ = 0.523, p < 0.001).
Psychological control is negatively associated with parental knowledge.
Parental warmth and behavioral control indirectly contribute to parental knowledge by promoting children's disclosure. "Parental warmth seems to provide the basis for high-quality children's disclosure."
Cultural differences exist: The association between behavioral control and parental knowledge was stronger in Eastern cultures compared to Western cultures.
Implications: Parents should focus on fostering warm, supportive relationships with their children to encourage open communication and voluntary disclosure.
C. Stress and Familismo in Latinx Adolescents (Montoro & Ceballo, 2021)

Core Argument: Both cultural and general stressors impact Latinx adolescents' psychological well-being, but familismo (a strong emphasis on family unity, support, and obligation) can serve as a protective factor.
Key Findings:Family-based cultural stressors were associated with increased depressive symptoms whereas familismo was associated with fewer depressive symptoms
Greater material need was associated with increased depressive symptoms and a less positive future orientation.
"Familismo protected adolescents from depressive symptoms linked to material hardship."
Racial discrimination is positively associated with anxiety
Implications: Interventions should leverage the strength of familismo to help Latinx adolescents cope with stress and promote positive mental health outcomes.
D. Family Acceptance and LGBT Adolescent Health (Ryan et al., 2010)

Core Argument: Family acceptance is a critical protective factor for LGBT adolescents, significantly impacting their mental and physical health in young adulthood.
Key Findings:"Family acceptance predicts greater self-esteem, social support, and general health status; it also protects against depression, substance abuse, and suicidal ideation and behaviors."
LGBT adolescents with low family acceptance were more than three times as likely to report suicidal ideation and suicide attempts compared to those with high family acceptance.
Latino, immigrant, religious, and low-socioeconomic status families appear to be less accepting, on average, of LGBT adolescents
Implications: Promote interventions that educate and support families in accepting their LGBT children to reduce health disparities and improve well-being.
III. Quotes

Frijns et al. (2010): "Only secrecy was a longitudinal predictor of adolescent internalizing (i.e., depression)..."
Liu et al. (2020): "Parental warmth seems to provide the basis for high-quality children's disclosure."
Montoro & Ceballo (2021): "Familismo protected adolescents from depressive symptoms linked to material hardship."
Ryan et al. (2010): "Family acceptance predicts greater self-esteem, social support, and general health status; it also protects against depression, substance abuse, and suicidal ideation and behaviors."
IV. Overall Implications
These studies collectively highlight the crucial role of family relationships in adolescent development. They emphasize the importance of open communication, parental warmth and support, cultural understanding, and acceptance in promoting adolescent well-being. The findings suggest that interventions should focus on strengthening family bonds, addressing both cultural and economic stressors, and promoting positive family dynamics to support healthy adolescent development.

item.title: Untitled Kanban
item.description: Adolescent7You aced a difficult exam, but you studied with a friend you parents don't approve of.You went to a party, and there was underage drinking. You did not participate, but you are unsure how your parents will react.You've started dating someone from a different cultural background, and you are unsure how your parents will react.You are feeling insecure about your appearance and have been considering extreme dieting.You are being bullied at school, but you don't want your parents to worry.You are questioning the religious beliefs that your parents taught you and exploring other spiritual paths.You have developed strong political views that differ significantly from your parents', and you are concerned about causing conflict.+ Add a cardParent4This parents values emotional connection and understanding. They prioritize open communication and want their child to feel safe sharing anything with them.(Controlling & Intrusive) This parent emphasizes rules and monitoring. They believe it is their responsibility to know everything about their child's life to keep them safe. This parent's psychological control may inhibit the child's disclosure for fear of a harmful reaction.(Anxious & Overprotective) This parents focused on safety and potential risks. They tend to worry excessively and may overreact to perceived threats.(Disengaged & Distant) This parent shows little interest in the adolescent's life. They may be preoccupied with their own problems or struggle to connect emotionally with their child.+ Add a cardExternal Influence5(Peer Pressure) Your friends encourage you to keep this a secret, saying your parents wouldn't understand and would just make things worse.(Cultural Norms) In your culture, this topic is considered taboo to discuss with parents, as it's seen as disrespectful or inappropriate.(Past Experiences) Last time you shared something similar, your parent overreacted, leading to a huge argument and a loss of trust.(Media Influence) A TV show you watched portrayed parents as being completely out of touch with teenagers' lives, making you think your parent might not understand.(Discrimination) An adolescent may not share a story of discrimination with their parents, fearing negative parental reactions.+ Add a card

item.title: Announcements
item.description:
Ohio History Connection
Mozarts
The oval
Scioto deer
Varsity club
The shoe
North market
Kelton house

In this week's spotlight for attractions, we have Ohio History Connection (https://www.ohiohistory.org/Links to an external site.)! The Ohio History Connection, formerly the Ohio Historical Society, is a statewide history organization with the mission to spark discovery of Ohio’s stories. As a nonprofit organization chartered in 1885, the Ohio History Connection carries out history services for Ohio and its citizens focused on preserving and sharing the state’s history. This includes housing the State Historic Preservation Office, the official state archives and the Community Engagement Department and managing more than 50 sites and museums across Ohio. I participated in their event on site. They hosted a bunch of reenactors there to reenact the 1950s! That event should also be happening again around the beginning of the year, so I hope to see you there! This museum is really cool to walk through, and they are always hosting events. 
For our restaurant, this week I chose Mozart's (https://mozartscafe.com/Links to an external site.)! Mozart's has been a Clintonville destination for over 20 years. Mozart’s brings Europe to Columbus through breakfast, lunch, dinner, and an incredible variety of decadent European pastries. This "taste of Austria" is accompanied by live piano music and jazz on select nights. Make sure you also check out the beautifully restored building, which was built in the 1920s.
Columbus lore... Columbus was first laid out in 1812 and incorporated in 1816. Columbus was not the original capital, but the state legislature chose to move the state government there after short periods in both Chillicothe and Zanesville. Columbus was chosen as the site for the new capital because of its central location within the state and access to transportation routes (primarily rivers) at that time. The legislature chose it as Ohio's capital over a number of other competitors, including Franklinton, Dublin, Worthington, and Delaware. Prior to the state legislature's decision in 1812, Columbus did not exist. The city was designed from the first as the state's capital, preparing itself for its role in Ohio's political, economic, and social life.
During the twentieth century, Columbus continued to grow and prosper. Due to lighted arches that spanned over the city's major north-south thoroughfare, High Street, Columbus earned the reputation of being the most "brilliantly illuminated city in the country." Most of these arches disappeared by mid century, but in 2002, the city began to construct new ones to celebrate Columbus' past. 
If you would like to add any suggestions, please feel free to comment below!
I hope this weather clears up and we get some sunny fall days. The leaves are falling! Where does the time go. 
Have a wonderful week, and please reach out to myself or Anna, our TA, if you have any questions or concerns. 
Warmest regards,
Lynn Reidinger

Another week, another (late) announcement,
I hope you are having a great week, we are halfway through, whether that's the semester or the week you decide! This week we will begin to look at the basic patterns of sexual orientation and behavior. We also look at the critiques on sexual attitudes, sex education, and the sexual double standard. By the end of this module, you will be able to answer some questions such as...

What is sexual orientation? How have attitudes toward homosexuality changed in the medical and scientific communities?
According to researchers, what is the role of genetics, evolution, and social environment in determining sexual orientation?
REMINDER: Please put aside enough time to watch 'How to Lose Your Virginity' (1 hour and 6 minutes) and 'Sex 101' (20 min). 
In this week's restaurant, I chose Belle's Bread. Tucked away in the Japanese marketplace located on Kenny Centre Mall, Belle’s BreadLinks to an external site. is a family-owned and -operated, French-inspired Japanese bakery. Takashi Takenaka opened the business after immigrating from Japan in 1972, and he pays homage to childhood treats with his red bean roll, frank roll, and curry and boiled egg doughnuts. The bear-shaped strawberry cream bun is all over social media, but the best-kept secret is the Mont Blanc roll with its layers of delicate, airy sweet cream and chestnuts. 
In Columbus Lore this week, our amazing student Doug Motz wrote this piece on the AIU & The LeVeque TowerLinks to an external site.. I learned so much information from this article, and it is just one piece of history from our city. Please take a moment to read through this article, if you get the chance. You know that big building that has those beautiful lights displayed at the top? Yup, that's this place! It has gone through it's fair share of history, and many owners. Apparently, the floodlights that were installed in 1989 had theatrical gel placed by hand to add the color to the tower. Though, this was updated in 2017 with LEDs that allow for color changes with ease. No more applying that gel by one very brave man. Thank you, Doug!! Just a wonderful piece of history to share with you all. 
Go outside and play in the leaves, take a moment to breathe. You have done so well, and I am so proud of you! Keep working hard as you always have, and remember to take care of yourself this week. :)
Warmest regards,
Lynn Reidinger

Goooooooood Evening Buckeyes!

Describe the contemporary social scrip that characterizes romantic relationship formation for college students and young adults.
Evaluate how relationship rituals such as texting, hooking up, online dating, datings apps are changing partner selection and intimate relationships.
Describe the roles that attraction and attractiveness play in mate selection and define personality characteristics that make someone attractive.
Critique marital attitudes over the past 150 years and their effect on mate selection.
On this week's Columbus lore, I thought I would bring it a little closer to home and look into OSU's history. You know that beautiful building you most likely walk by regularly called University Hall? Well, do I have some interesting facts for you.
This was the first classroom building opened in 1873! 

“Announcements-1.png” could not be found.
“Announcements-2.png” could not be found.

On the first day of classes in September 1873, the students entered an unfinished University Hall. This first building on campus was a classroom building, library, administrative office building, and it had apartments for faculty and dormitory rooms for male students. (The students moved out when the first dormitory opened in 1874). It even housed the Geology Museum until Orton Hall opened in 1893. University Hall had a chapel as well, which was originally used for a daily religious service.
In the spring of 1968 concern about the building's structural integrity led to a study of its safety. It was determined to be unsafe, and on May 9, 1968, the Board of Trustees instructed the administrative officials of the University to move everything out of the building. University Hall was torn down in September 1971. Today’s University Hall occupies almost exactly the same spot as the original University Hall (it is slightly east). When the original University Hall was torn down, there was quite a bit of discussion over which architectural style the new building should have. Eventually, University officials decided to make the new University Hall look the same as the original building on the outside. Although less ornamental, and smaller, today’s University Hall is still a landmark on campus. It was completed in 1976. (https://library.osu.edu/site/buckeyestroll/university-hall/Links to an external site.)
For a random Columbus restaurant, I wanted something close to campus. I chose Emmett's Cafe! This bakery/cafe is located in the Old North. Inspired by Australian coffee culture, Emmett’s is the top pick for morning hangouts with a flat white or cold brew. This laid-back spot recently opened a second, much larger and brighter location at the Open Air building, a renovated school building in Old North. Open until 2pm during the work week, the cafe offers wifi and plenty of space to spread out with a few coworkers. Food options go far beyond pastries, with options like overnight oats, filling breakfast sandwiches, grain bowls, wraps, and even a wagyu burger. 
A random attraction, one that is certainly not everyone's taste, but I thought I would share nonetheless, Wagner-Hagans Auto Museum! This auto museum is a private collection here in Columbus that is free and open to the public. This is a small museum without regular staff, so you do need to call and schedule an appointment to tour the museum.
I am certainly not one to be personal, but I thought it was only appropriate to share. I got married this weekend! My husband and I decided to elope and read our vows in Hocking Hills. It was only appropriate we read our vows near Ash Cave, since that is the new last name I am taking. If you see me signing Millie Ash, that is my new name! You are more than welcome to call me Lynn or Millie. I will include a picture of Ted and me at the trailhead!
I hope the cool weather is a welcomed relief to the blistering heat we had over the last several weeks. Get that pumpkin spice latte for yourself, you deserve that treat! I can't wait to see the leaves falling all over campus. 
Warmest regards,
Millie Lynn Ash (Lynn Reidinger)

Hey Class,
I apologize for missing our weekly announcement last week, but I was unfortunately not feeling well. We can't skip this week, what if some of you are waiting on this week's Columbus lore? As always, I will have interesting history, activities, and suggested restaurants below.
You worked through your midterm, WOO! I am so proud of each of you for getting to this point in the semester. I can't believe we are almost finished. It has been a pleasure getting to know each and every one of you. Thank you to each of you that congratulated me on my marriage, and this week seems very fitting!
This week we look at marriage and cohabitation. Be mindful as we reflect on diversity, inequality, and social change in terms of marriage. We will consider how marital quality changes across the life course and illustrate the hallmarks of poor marital communication. Do you know what are the predictors of a high quality, satisfying marriage? What specific relationships come to mind when you think of a healthy marriage?
This week's assignments are outlined below. As always, we accept your assignments 24-hours late with a 2-point deduction on your essays and discussions, and a 1-point deduction for your weekly reflections. We are unable to accept your InQuizitive quizzes late. 
Please read:

Chapter 8 of The Family - Cohen (2020)
The Suffocation Model: Why Marriage in America Is Becoming an All-or-Nothing Institution (Finkel, 2015)
The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse (Why Marriages Succeed and Fail - Gottman, 1994)
Class Differences in Cohabitation Processes (Sassler and Miller, 2011)
Reminders, 

InQuizitive: Chapter 8 (Cohabitation and Marriage): 10/25/2023
Engage Discussion 8: Cohabitation: 10/27/2023
Essay 8: The True Hard Work of Love and Relationships: 10/30/2023
Reflection 8: 10/30/2023
Columbus Lore: The Oval!



Originally, there was no formal plan for an Oval. The space in front of University Hall was intended to be a large rectangle, in the tradition of an English manor.
By 1900, however, the Oval began to form as buildings cropped up around the open space. In 1905 there were no sidewalks and students joked of people disappearing into the mud. The mud paths were studied and eventually their locations influenced where sidewalks were placed.
The Oval also contains several memorials. The most well-known is perhaps “The Five Brothers,” which is composed of five elm trees planted as a class gift. The originals were planted in 1891 and succumbed to Dutch Elm Disease, the last in 1971; the replacements were planted in 1987. Other memorials include the flagpole in front of Bricker Hall, dedicated in 1917 to graduates killed in WWI, and a sundial, a gift from the class of 1905, which now stands in Sphinx Plaza.
The Oval has been home to commencements, rallies, student demonstrations, cavalry drills, contests, and even a musical chairs contest for charity.
Riveting Restaurants: Anthony Thomas Candy Company.!

Anthony Zanetos immigrated to the United States from Greece in 1907. His first job was as an apprentice candy maker in a local candy shop in Columbus, Ohio. It was in 1916, when Anthony experienced the urge to go into business for himself. This decision molded the lives of four generations. In 1932, Anthony opened the Co-op Dairy at the corner of Chicago Avenue and Broad Street in Franklinton. It was Anthony’s dream for a father and son business. In 1945 Anthony’s son Tom, returned home from service following W.W.II. Together they started Anthony’s Confectionary where the Co-op Dairy used to be. Following the war, sugar was rationed and Veterans that were in the candy business could get a 30,000-pound annual allotment of sugar, which made Tom a valuable asset and an instant partner with his father. Realizing the quality of the candy was creating a demand, Tom and his father decided to make it a full time trade, and using their first names they formed the Anthony-Thomas Candy Company in 1952.
Astounding Activities: The Scioto Deer 
“Announcements-8.png” could not be found.
You may have probably seen at least one of the three bronze deer sculptures located throughout Columbus, but do you know why they’re actually there? It’s okay, neither did I. These friendly, relaxed-looking deer were added to the Scioto Mile as part of the big rehabilitation project in 2014 that turned the area into the incredible multi-use park and trail space it is now.There are a total of three deer along the Scioto River admiring the river, and they were put in during the renovation. Two of these funky art pieces are behind COSI and the other is on the Rich Street Bridge watching over our beloved city. So don’t worry everyone, the deer are protecting us. 
I hope you all have a great week. I should be on tomorrow for our office hours if you may need anything (My office hours are Tuesdays from 1p-2p). Please take some time this week to soak in some sun and enjoy this fall weather. You have worked so hard to get to this point!
Warmest regards,
Millie Lynn Ash

IT'S HALLOWEEN!!!
This is my favorite holiday, and it makes me so happy to see people dressed up while walking around campus. Make sure to grab some candy for yourself (... getting it on sale tomorrow does in fact count), and take it easy this week. This week's topic some of you may already have some experience with, whether directly or indirectly, parenting. We will analyze societal expectations and attitudes around parenthood and childlessness. We will also look at concepts of intensive motherhood, helicopter parenting, and co-parenting. 
REMINDERS:
InQuizitive (Chapter 9): 11/1
Discussion (Intensive Parenting): 11/3
Essay 9: 11/5
Reflection 9: 11/5
On this week's Columbus lore, we are back on campus with my personal favorite: Mirror Lake

It is very fitting to choose this wonderful place as our topic for Columbus Lore. The first contact with the lake was not with a person, as its history might suggest, but a horiculture wagon! Students rolled the wagon into the lake as a Halloween prank in 1895. The lake has a history of dunking freshman and tug-of-war across the lake. The Lantern depicted a freshman in the middle of the lake, dubbed the 'Freshman Bathtub.' In the 1920s, the tradition of dunking freshmen into the lake had been given approval from the student council and the university president. The rules: Freshmen must wear a specific cap at all times and not step food on the Long Walk, the brick path across the Oval leading up to Thompson library. Only assigned enforcers of the Bucket and Dipper club were allowed to toss freshmen into the lake. The last the lake would see of any tug-of-war across the lake was around the 1950s. It was stated the 3 minutes it took for one side to take over the other felt like 3 hours for people in attendance! In 1964, an engaged couple 'quarreled' at the lake; the man took back the engagement ring and threw it in the lake, and the woman went searching for it in a bikini. She was initially arrested but the executive dean finally allowed her to resume the search in different attire. She found the ring!
“Announcements-9.png” could not be found.
Riveting Restaurants: Thurn's Specialty Meats
On easter weekend in 1886, Alois 'Grospop' Thurn opened up a stall at the old Central Market and began selling old world style, processed items. He immigrated to Columbus from Germany a few years before and had begun working at a processing plant. He used the scraps to make meals for his family, and then his neighbors. In 1958, with the new interstate encroaching, his son, Alois, along with his grandsons, Robert, Paul and Leo, began construction on a new plant and storeroom.  This facility is still in use today.  In 1965, the Thurn brothers moved out the Central Market, 2 years before its demise.  Since that time, 530 Greenlawn Avenue is the only place to buy Thurn’s products.
Astounding Activities: 
“Announcements-10.png” could not be found.
For those of you who have not heard, Columbus has a very special field of corn. The Field of Corn is an art installation that playfully reshapes the landscape. Rows of towering concrete corn cobs invite contemplation on themes of agriculture, transformation, and artistic expression. Unearth the artist’s vision behind this unique creation and its role in Columbus’s cultural tapestry.
There was the first frost, and I definitely felt slow getting to class this morning. Mr. Ted has been coming to campus with me, so if you ever see us walking by don't be afraid to say hi!
Have a fantastic week!
Warmest regards,
Millie Lynn Ash

Hi Buckeyes!
Though we are not covering anything this week, I wanted to send an announcement out to all of you regarding the event that will take place for each of you tomorrow. Thanksgiving is a time to gather with our families, eat some nice hearty food, and take a wondrous carb nap afterwards! For some, you may not celebrate or do anything at all. 
My home is open to each and every one of you if you do not have anyone to celebrate the holidays with. You have become a part of my family over this semester, even if I still have yet to actually meet you in person. As we have learned, family is a broad spectrum that includes a variety of circumstances, contexts, and people. Our family includes those we love, those we don't, those who would answer their phone in the middle of the night, those we turn to in times of need, those we learn from, and so many more. Whatever role your family plays in your life, please know you will be forever in mine. I will always be here to support you on your journey to wherever you are going. 
To change tune a bit, do you really know the origins of Thanksgiving? Thanksgiving is known for its yummy food and terrible traffic, but did you know the first European Thanksgiving in the United States was celebrated in 1564? This tradition, though centuries old, was not the first. The credit for that event goes to Native Americans.
From contemporaneous records, we know that the Pilgrims and Native Americans had turkey and other game birds, as well as sea foods, venison, Indian corn, beans, berries, and nuts. They drank mostly beer, wine, and whiskies - all safer than the local water. 
Thanksgiving as a holiday originates from the Native American philosophy of giving without expecting anything in return. In the first celebration of this holiday, the Wampanoag tribe provided not only the food for the feast but also the teachings of agriculture and hunting (corn, beans, wild rice, and turkey are some specific examples of foods introduced by Native Americans).
Though you may have known about the information above, did you know that the fourth Thursday in November (Thanksgiving) is recognized as the National Day of Mourning for Native Americans and their families.  For many Native Americans, Thanksgiving is a day of mourning and protest since it commemorates the arrival of settlers in North America and the centuries of oppression and genocide that followed. 
While some Native Americans have chosen to reject the Thanksgiving holiday entirely, many embrace the positive messages of the day and choose to put aside thoughts about its complex history. This is because the idea of giving thanks is central to Native heritage and culture. In this way, Thanksgiving is simply a chance to appreciate the good things in life, like family, community, and the riches of the land. Long before settlers arrived, Native tribes celebrated the autumn harvest and the gift of Mother Earth's abundance. Native American spirituality, traditionally and today, emphasizes gratitude for creation, care for the environment, and recognition of the human need for communion with nature and others. 
Now, regardless of the day's ambiguous origin, many Native Americans will gather with friends and family and use the day to eat good food (many of the classic Thanksgiving dishes are inspired by indigenous foods) and give thanks. 
I hope you learned something from above, and remember to actually rest over break. I know how easy it is to just work through it, as I probably will. Do as I say, not as I do! Take care of yourselves, and drive safe. Tonight is the heaviest drinking night of the year, and I passed many accidents on my way today. Your life and safety matter more than those extra couple minutes you save. 
Whether you celebrate or don't, be kind, grateful, and gentle with yourself and others this break. Don't add to the population, don't subtract from the population, and don't get sent to prison. I can't becoming an auntie just yet!
We are almost finished, I can't believe how quickly the time has flown by. It has been an absolute pleasure getting to know each and every one of you over the last several months. Remember, you always have a home with me. 
Warmest regards,
Millie Lynn Ash
Happy Tuesday everyone!
Though this announcement will be reaching you a day later than usual, I still wanted to check in on everyone. This week's content is critical to consider in our current political sphere. We will analyze social issues that have impacted inequality and social change with regard to family life among Native Americans, African Americans, Latinos, Asian Americans, and Americans from the Middle East. I want you to examine your own racial/ethnic identity and privilege and how it manifests in family life. We discuss examples of implicit bias and microaggressions and how they impact the individual and family. 
We will be reading Chapter 3 in Cohen (2020) this week, which is posted under the top module labelled 'Textbook Information.' You will also be taking a look at a few videos on racism and microaggressions. 
Things to keep in mind for this week:

Chapter 3: Race, Ethnicity, and Immigration (due January 29th)

item.title: HW 1
item.description:
Descriptive statistics describe the state of the data. It summarizes and describes the characteristics of a data set whereas inferential statistics infer information about the sample participants based on their data. Inferential statistics uses data from a sample to make predictions or draw conclusions about a larger population. The results allow us to analyze the sample and infer predictions about the larger population.


The General Linear Model (GLM)
Assumes the residuals (variation of variables) will be 'normally distributed'
Betas are regression weights that are optimally estimated based on their contribution of each variable to reasonable predictions of Y.
Absolute value of b depends on the metric scale of the x variable that they modify
The Generalized Linear Model (GLzM)
Extension of GLM
Outcome variable follows different distributions than the 'normal distribution' (i.e., probability distributions, binomial distributions, gamma distributions, etc.)
Binary/dichotomous, count data, etc.
Outcome variable is traditionally related to the linear model through link functions.



Categories that are distinct and which do not have numerical value
Examples
School
Eye color
Marital status


Numerical values that only signify ranking.
Examples
Risk level
Likert-scale questions


Numerical data that has equibalent ranges between values but no meaningful zero.
Examples
SAT scores
Percentile rankings
Temperature in Fahrenheit or Celsius


Same as interval, but with a meaningful zero.
Data can be ranked, intervals are consistent.
Examples
Height
Age
Weight
Temperature in Kelvin


A One-Way Independent ANOVA


Add a period at the end of the statements. The text should turn from red to blue and he should be able to run the selected lines of code.

item.title: HW 2
item.description:
The change in the dependent (outcome) variable for a one unit change in the independent (predictor) variable, while holding all other variables constant.
Expressed in the original units of the dependent (outcome) and independent (predictor) variables.


The values obtained after standardizing all variables (both dependent and independent variables) to have a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.
This allows for the newly calculated variables to represent the change in the dependent variable (in standard deviations) for one-standard deviation change in the value of the independent variable.



Measures the relationship between two variables without controlling for any other variable(s) using simple correlation.
We would use this when we want to understand the simple bivariate relationship between two variables.
We would likely use the Pearson Correlation Coefficient R for this type of analysis.


Measures the correlation between x and y while controlling for x2 (on both x and y).
We would likely use this when we want to understand the direct relationship between two variables, independent of influence of other variables.


Measures the relationship between two variables while controlling for the effect of one or more variables on only one of the two variables.
Correlation between x and y while controlling for x2 (on x1 only)
We would likely use this when we want to understand the exact contribution of an independent (predictor) variable to the dependent (outcome) variable, after taking into account the influence of other variables on the independent (predictor) variable.



All predictors are added into the regression model at the same time.
The model evaluates the contribution of each predictor to the outcome variable while controlling for all other predictors.
R-squared is a static value that represents the variance explained in the outcome variable by the collective set of predictors.
Continuous variable is added as it is
Nominal Variable must be dummy coded
Variables with non-zero values should be ‘centered’


Predictors are entered into the model in a pre-specified order based theory-driven blocks.
The model is built in blocks (steps) with each block adding one or more predictors. The change in the model’s R-squared is assessed at every step.
A series of multiple-regression are performed, with each block being added to the next until all variables are included in the model.
The final block of hierarchical multiple regression = simultaneous multiple regression.
Very useful to look at the change in R-squared for each variable or blocks of variables
Allow for testing hypotheses in the order of importance/priority of predictors.
Squared semi-partial correlation provides the unique variance explained by a given variable.


Predictors are added/removed from the model based on statistical criteria such as p-values or R-squared change rather than being theory-driven. Predictors are added/removed in data-driven blocks.
Mathematically derives the highest R-squared value with the least number of predictors.
CAUTION: NEVER USE THIS METHOD UNLESS STUDY IS ABSOLUTELY EXPLORATORY.


Most predictive variables are added first


Least predictive variables are removed first



When you square the semi-partial correlation, it yields the proportion of the variance of y uniquely explained by x while controlling for all other predictors.



Analyze > Regression > Linear
Move dependent variable to Dependent. Move independent variable(s) to the Independent(s).
- In Statistics, select Estimates (under Regression Coefficients), Model Fit, Descriptives, and Durbin-Watson (under Residuals, independence of errors). Click Continue.
- In Plots, select Histograms and Normal Probability Plot (under Standardized Residual Plots). Move ZPRED under Y. Move ZRESID to X. Click Continue.
- In Save, select Cook’s (under Distances). Click Continue.
3.     Click OK.


The relationship between the independent (predictor) variables and the dependent (outcome) variables is linear.
How to Check

Use Scatterplots to visualize relationships. Click Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot.
Click Simple Scatter. Click Define.
Move your dependent variable (outcome) to the Y-Axis. Move your independent variable (predictor) to the X-Axis.
If the scatterplot is approximately linear, the assumption is met.
If not linear, apply transformation.


Observations are independent of each other (no autocorrelation, where observations are NOT independent)
How to Check

Use the Durbin-Watson test by clicking the option under Linear Regression: Statistics.
If the Durbin-Watson test falls within the range of 1.5 – 2.5, the assumption is met.
If data is autocorrelated, use alternative models such as the generalized least squares (GLS) model.


The residuals (errors) have constant variance across all levels of independent variable(s).
How to Check

Plot residuals vs. predicted values and look for a random scatter.
In SPSS, request Linear Regression Plots. Move Y > ZPRED. Move X > ZRESID.
If the scatterplots shows no overall pattern, the assumption is met.
If assumption is violated, you can transform the dependent variable, use standard errors, or apply weighted least squares (WLS).


The residuals (errors) are normally distributed.
How to Check (For None or One Grouping Variable)

Click Analyze > Descriptives > Explore
Transfer the variable that needs to be tested for normality into the Dependent List box.
Click on Statistics. Leave Descriptives selected.
Click the Plots. Select Factor Levels Together under Boxplots. Select Stem-and-Leaf under Descriptive. Select Normality Plots with Tests. Click Continue.
Click OK.
Check Shapiro-Wilk Test of Normality, Normal P-P Plot, Histogram, and Skewness/Kurtosis.
If the Sig. value of the Shapiro-Wilk Test is greater than p = .05, the data is normal.
If it is below .05, the data significantly deviate from a normal distribution.
If the points are generally along the diagonal of the Normal P-P Plot, the assumption is met.
If the Histogram is approximately normal (distribution curve is bell-shaped), the assumption is met.
If Skewness and Kurtosis are between +2 and -2, the assumption is met.



How far a case is from some point of reference


Identifies the distance of cases from the mean (s) of predictor (s). Extreme cases in multivariate space are found via a cut-off point (critical value of Chi-Square Test)


Measure the distance between an observed value and its predicted value that have all been converted to z-scores.
Typically flag cases if they are 2 or 3 standard deviations away from the mean.


How far a point deviates from the mean of that variable.
Gauges the influence of the observed values over the predicted values.
Ranges from zero to (N – 1) / N
Average value is (k + 1) / N
No greater than 2 (k + 1) / N or 3 (k + 1) / N


The degree to which a variable can ‘pull’ the regression towards itself.
Cook's Distance
Measures the overall influence of a case on the model
Typically flagged if value is over 1


Factor loadings help determine which variable is associated with which latent factor. For example, several likert-scale questions on a questionnaire observing psychological outcomes may load highly on a ‘depressive/depression’ factor, showing they measure the same underlying construct. Higher values of factor loadings (e.g., > .4 or .5) indicate that a variable is a strong indicator of that factor. Lower values suggest the variable is less relevant to that factor. EFA can allow us to group variables with higher factor loadings on the same factor, reducing the complexity of our data.



3
The eigenvalue represents the amount of variance explained by each factor. If using the eigenvalue cutoff of 1, the cutoff is greater than 1 because the retained factors explain more variance. This can be seen on the Scree plot where there is a point where the slope of the curve changes, which is usually the cutoff for the number of factors we would retain. Factors to the left of the cutoff are considered meaningful. This is why there are only 3 out of the original 12 factors that were extracted from the analysis. The first three factors account for more of the variance in the model.

item.title: HW 3
item.description:
A moderator is a variable that affects the strength or direction of the relationship between an independent variable (x) and a dependent variable (y).
A mediator is a variable that explains the mechanisms or process through which an independent variable (x) affects a dependent variable (y).




The purpose of the ‘seed’ option in a line of PROCESS syntax is to lock the random number generator. This ensures that the findings remain consistent across multiple runs of the analysis. Without specifying a ‘seed’ value, the random number generator would draw different values each time, leading to slightly different results.


When a covariable absorbs variable from both the predictor and the error term, it can lead to:





Sphericity is an assumption in repeated measures ANOVA that states the variance of the differences between all pairs of within-subject conditions (levels of the independent variable) should be equal. This means that if we have three time points (A, B, C), then the variance of (A – B) ≈ variance of (A – C) ≈ variance of (B – C).
Sphericity is a special case of homogeneity of variance assumption and is specific to repeated measures designs.
Potential Consequences of Violating Sphericity
Inflated Type I Errors Rate (False Positives)
Standard F-tests assume sphericity, so violating it increases the risk of finding a significant effect when none actually exists.
The p-values become too small, leading to incorrect conclusions.
Reduced Statistical Power (False Negative)
If sphericity is violated and not corrected, the test might be too conservative, making it harder to detect real effects (Type II Error: Failing to detect a true effect).
Distorted F-ratios
The denominator degrees of freedom in the F-test get inflated which makes the ANOVA test statistics biased. This impacts the accuracy of hypothesis testing.





Long-Format Data
