item.title: Mediation
item.description:
Single Mediation
Moderation






Mediation examines how the effect of an independent variable (IV) on a dependent variable (DV) is transmitted through a third variable, called the mediator (M). In simple mediation, there is one mediator.


To determine if the IV influences the DV directly and/or indirectly via the mediator. The model splits the total effect into


The portion of the effect of IV on DV that is not explained by the mediator.


The portion of the effect that is transmitted from IV to DV through the mediator.




Relationships among IV, mediator, and DV are linear.


Scatterplots:
Go to Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot and plot DV vs. IV and DV vs. M.
Look for a straight-line pattern.
Residuals vs. Predicted Plot:
Run Analyze > Regression > Linear…; click Plots… to assign standardized predicted values (X-axis) and standardized residuals (Y-axis).
Criteria: No systematic pattern (i.e., randomness, with any curve test yielding p > .05).


Residuals have constant variance across all levels of predictors.


Examine the same residuals vs. predicted plot for an even spread (no funnel shape).


Residuals are approximately normally distributed.


Create histograms and Q–Q plots using Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Histogram or Q–Q plot options.
Criteria: Skewness values less than |2.0| and kurtosis values less than |7.0|; Q–Q plot points should lie near the diagonal line.


Observations are independent.


Confirm via your study design.
Review the Durbin–Watson statistic from your regression output (values between 1.5 and 2.5 are acceptable).


There are no unmeasured variables that confound the relationship between the mediator and DV.


This is primarily a design issue; however, consider including control variables if needed.



Go to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS vX by Andrew Hayes
Choose Model 4 (designed for simple mediation).
Set the DV, IV, and mediator in the appropriate boxes.
Enable bootstrapping (commonly set to 5,000 samples) to obtain robust confidence intervals (CIs) for the indirect effect.
Click OK.


Direct Path (IV → M):
Example: a = 0.40, SE = 0.10, p = .001
Path from Mediator to DV (M → DV, controlling for IV):
Example: b = 0.50, SE = 0.12, p = .002
Indirect Effect (a × b):
Example: 0.40 × 0.50 = 0.200.40 \times 0.50 = 0.20
Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.08, 0.35] (does not include zero → significant mediation).
Direct Effect (IV → DV controlling for M):
Example: c′ = 0.25, SE = 0.09, p = .005
Total Effect (IV → DV without mediator):
Example: c = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p < .001


A mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 4) with 5,000 bootstrap samples to examine whether [Mediator] mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. The total effect of [IV] on [DV] was significant (b = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p < .001). When [Mediator] was entered into the model, the direct effect decreased (b = 0.25, SE = 0.09, p = .005). The indirect effect was significant (b = 0.20, SE = 0.07, 95% CI [0.08, 0.35]), indicating that [Mediator] partially mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV].





Parallel mediation involves multiple mediators that operate simultaneously. Each mediator is theorized to transmit the effect of the IV on the DV independently.


To examine whether different processes (mediators) independently contribute to the effect of the IV on the DV. This model allows you to assess which mediator(s) play a significant role and to what extent.


IV → Mediator 1 → DV
IV → Mediator 2 → DV
(Mediators do not influence one another)



Generate scatterplots for DV vs. each mediator.
Run separate regression analyses for each mediator (DV as outcome, mediator as predictor) and inspect residuals vs. predicted plots.
Criteria: Residuals should show no systematic pattern.


Create histograms and Q–Q plots for the residuals of each regression.
Criteria: Skewness < |2.0| and kurtosis < |7.0|.


Run a correlation matrix (Analyze > Correlate > Bivariate) among the mediators.
Criteria: Inter-mediator correlations should be moderate (ideally, r < 0.80) to avoid redundancy.


As with simple mediation, verify study design and check the Durbin–Watson statistic (1.5–2.5).


Navigate to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS vX.
Use Model 4; PROCESS allows entering multiple mediators simultaneously.
Enter the IV, DV, and list all mediators.
Enable bootstrapping (e.g., 5,000 samples) to obtain confidence intervals for each indirect effect.
Click OK.



Example: a1 = 0.30, b1 = 0.40 → Indirect effect = 0.30 × 0.40 = 0.12
Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.03, 0.22] (significant if CI does not include zero, p = .012).


Example: a2 = 0.25, b2 = 0.35 → Indirect effect = 0.25 × 0.35 = 0.0875
Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.01, 0.18] (significant, p = .025).


Sum of individual indirect effects (if both are significant).


Example: c′ = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p < .001


A parallel mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 4) with 5,000 bootstrap samples to evaluate whether [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] independently mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. The indirect effect through [Mediator 1] was significant (b = 0.12, SE = 0.06, 95% CI [0.03, 0.22], p = .012), as was the indirect effect through [Mediator 2] (b = 0.09, SE = 0.05, 95% CI [0.01, 0.18], p = .025). The direct effect of [IV] on [DV] remained significant (b = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p < .001), suggesting that both mediators contributed uniquely to the overall relationship.”





Serial mediation (also called chain mediation) involves two or more mediators arranged in a specific sequential order. The IV affects the first mediator, which in turn affects the second mediator, and so on, eventually influencing the DV.


To investigate the process by which the IV impacts the DV through a chain of mediators, highlighting the step-by-step mechanism and temporal ordering of effects.



Generate scatterplots and residual vs. predicted plots for each link: IV → M1, M1 → M2, and M2 → DV.
Use histograms and Q–Q plots for residuals in each regression.
Criteria: As before, look for random dispersion, skewness < |2.0|, kurtosis < |7.0|, and Durbin–Watson between 1.5 and 2.5.


There must be theoretical or empirical support for the hypothesized order (e.g., M1 influences M2).
Run intermediate regressions (e.g., regress M2 on M1) and ensure that coefficients are significant (p < .05) in line with your theory.


Consider and control for variables that may confound the relationships between mediators if necessary.


Go to Analyze > Regression > PROCESS vX.
Choose Model 6 (designed for serial mediation).
Enter the IV, DV, and mediators in the specific sequential order.
Click Options:
Enable bootstrapping (e.g., 5,000 samples) to obtain confidence intervals.
Click OK.


Path IV → Mediator 1:
Example: a1 = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p = .001
Path Mediator 1 → Mediator 2:
Example: d = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p = .001
Path Mediator 2 → DV (controlling for IV and M1):
Example: b2 = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p = .002
Sequential Indirect Effect (IV → M1 → M2 → DV):
Calculation: a1 × d × b2 = 0.35 × 0.45 × 0.30 = 0.0473
Bootstrapped 95% CI: [0.01, 0.10] (if CI does not include zero, the effect is significant, e.g., p = .018).
Direct Effect (IV → DV controlling for mediators):
Example: c′ = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p < .001


A serial mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro (Model 6) with 5,000 bootstrap samples to test whether [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] sequentially mediated the relationship between [IV] and [DV]. The analysis indicated that [IV] significantly predicted [Mediator 1] (b = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p = .001), and [Mediator 1] significantly predicted [Mediator 2] (b = 0.45, SE = 0.10, p = .001). Furthermore, [Mediator 2] significantly predicted [DV] (b = 0.30, SE = 0.08, p = .002). The sequential indirect effect was significant (b = 0.047, SE = 0.02, 95% CI [0.01, 0.10], p = .018), indicating that the effect of [IV] on [DV] was transmitted via [Mediator 1] and [Mediator 2] in sequence. The direct effect of [IV] on [DV] remained significant (b = 0.35, SE = 0.09, p < .001), suggesting partial mediation.



Check Assumptions in SPSS:
Generate scatterplots, residual vs. predicted plots, histograms, and Q–Q plots.
Verify diagnostic values: skewness (< |2.0|), kurtosis (< |7.0|), Durbin–Watson (1.5–2.5), and inter-mediator correlations (r < 0.80 for parallel mediation).
For serial mediation, confirm intermediate regression steps are significant (p < .05).
Conduct Mediation Analysis with PROCESS:
Use the appropriate model: Model 4 for simple and parallel mediation; Model 6 for serial mediation.
Enter variables as specified and enable bootstrapping (commonly 5,000 samples) to generate 95% confidence intervals.
Interpret Output:
Evaluate p-values for each path (significant if p < .05).
For indirect effects, confirm that bootstrapped confidence intervals do not include zero.
item.guid: University Resources/Current/GLM 2/Mediation.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 1. Introduction to Secondary Data Analysis
item.description:
In the broadest sense, Secondary Data are collected by someone else
If the data were collected by the researcher for the specific purpose or analysis under consideration, it is Primary Data
Traditionally, our field has downplayed the importance and value of secondary data, but times are changing.
The use of secondary data has a long and rich tradition in the sociology, economies, etc.


Large government-funded datasets
State-wide or district-level school records
Journal supplements
Author websites


Quantitative and Qualitative
Restricted and public-use
Direct (e.g., biomarker data) and indirect observations (e.g., self-report)



Economics
Study design and data collection already completed - saves time and money
Access
To international and cross-historical data would otherwise take years and millions of dollars to collect
Quality
Data collection process is informed by expertise and professionalism that may not be available to smaller research projects
External Validity
Studies funded by the government generally involve larger samples that are more representative of the target population.
Statistical Power
Over sampling of low prevalence groups allows for increased power and precision
Breadth
Datasets often contain many variables


Using it is the hardest part
Study design and data collection already completed
Data may lack depth. The greater the breadth the harder it is to measure a construct in depth.
Constructs may be defined by a single item or a subset of items that have reliability/validity concerns
Posthoc measurement models maybe unsuccessful
Certain fields or departments may place less value on secondary data analysis
May require knowledge of survey statistics/methods which is not generally provided by basic graduate statistics courses.
The temptation of a statistical fishing trip
Great research is driven by a good research question that is shaped by theory
Data analysis is done to refine our understanding of a topic and to develop theories by testing empirical hypotheses
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Secondary Data Analysis/1. Introduction to Secondary Data Analysis/1. Introduction to Secondary Data Analysis.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Answering Developmental Questions Using Secondary Data
item.description:
Bibliography: Davis‐Kean, P. E., Jager, J., & Maslowsky, J. (2015). Answering Developmental Questions Using Secondary Data. Child Development Perspectives, 9(4), 256–261. https://doi.org/10.1111/cdep.12151
Type: Journal Article
Title: Answering Developmental Questions Using Secondary Data,
Author: Davis‐Kean, Pamela E.; Jager, Justin; Maslowsky, Julie;
Journal: Child Development Perspectives,
Volume: 9,
Issue: 4
Pages: 256-261
Year: 2015
DOI: 10.1111/cdep.12151
ISSN: 1750-8592, 1750-8606

Secondary data analysis of large longitudinal and national data sets is a standard method used in many social sciences to answer complex questions regarding behavior. In this article, we detail the advantages of using these data sets to study developmental questions across the life span. First, we provide an overview of how using secondary data can increase studies’ scientiﬁc integrity. Then, we detail where and how data sets can be obtained that answer speciﬁc questions. Finally, we discuss methodological issues related to using longitudinal, population data sets. These data sets can enhance science and test theories by increasing the rigor and generalizability of research to the general population, making secondary data analysis an important method to consider.


Keywords: Need to Read


Primary data are collected by an individual or a team of researchers and are often based on the theory or models of the researcher or research team.
These data are also generally proprietary and not shared with the larger research community.
In contrast, secondary data analysis uses data collected by other researchers or organizations, and the users are generally not part of the design of the study. These data sets (e.g., most national studies) have been collected for the use of the research community or have been made available for other researchers to use (e.g., in data archives).


These data sets were collected based on the research theories and models of the primary researchers and include extensive measurements on the areas of interest to the research team.
Although some data sets remain proprietary to the original researcher or research team, new regulations on data sharing from the National Institutes of Health and the National Science Foundation are increasing the amount of data available for secondary data analysis.
Many secondary data sets contain similarities in measurement that allow many data sets to be combined using techniques such as integrative data analysis, a technique that is especially useful for data sets that represent highly selective groups (e.g., children of alcoholics) that would be difficult to find in a general population sample.
Combining the data sets increases the sample size and thus the power to examine these groups.
Using secondary data sets, especially those collected at the population level, increases statistical power and external validity as a result of a larger sample size and greater diversity of respondents (with regard to race, ethnicity, and socioeconomic status).
This advantage, combined with reducing the time and money it takes to collect one's own longitudinal data, makes secondary data analysis a good option.
These data resources are easy to obtain.


In the US, the two largest social science data archives are the Interuniversity Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR) and the Murray Research Archive.

ICPSR requires affiliation with a member institution. Some data sets are available for immediate download while others require an application explaining the scientific purpose for data use.
Data are generally free though fees may apply for digitization of not-yet digital materials or other labor-intensive data-preparation tasks.


Archives are easily searchable, including the ability to search by study topic or variable name.
Searching by study topic is helpful when the researcher is looking for studies focused on a specific subject. Searching by variable name is helpful when the researcher is looking for studies focused on a specific subject.
Searching for variable name is helpful when the researcher is interested in a particular variable, such as rates of endorsement or forms of measurement of a variable across studies.
Most archives allow researchers to perform basic descriptive analyses online before downloading a data set, including frequency counts for each variable and tabular analysis.
Scientists can determine whether a variable of interest has a large enough sample size, enough variance in responses, or not too much missing data for the new study.
Such online analyses are also useful for testing a new hypothesis before collecting new data on the topic or performing preliminary analyses for grant applications.


The most important step is to read all the data documentation - text documents posted in the data archive alongside the data.
Understanding and properly accounting for the sampling frame and necessary weights are crucial in producing accurate results, and the study documentation contains the necessary information.
Secondary data rarely have all the measures to answer investigators' questions.
Using data that have been collected by others typically means that measures for some of the constructs germane to the research question will be missing.
Because population data sets typically measure a broad set of constructs with limited measurement on any given construct, they often are not ideal for answering nuanced questions that require in-depth measurement.
Once a researcher has addressed the issue of obtaining the data set or sets to address his or her research questions and whether they adequately answer the relevant research questions, additional statistical issues must be considered in analyzing this data.



Because oversampling of one or more subpopulations is common in population-based studies, researchers often must apply a same weight if they want their findings to generalize to the target population.
Subpopulations that are underrepresented in the sample relative to the target population have sample weights larger than 1.0, while the opposite holds for subpopulations overrepresented in the sample relative to the target population. When no sample weights are applied, it is as if a sample weight of 1.0 is uniformly applied to all subpopulations.
In effect, this assumes all subpopulations are represented accurately within the sample, leading to biased estimates when this assumption does not hold.
Typically, the appropriate set of sample weights and its corresponding variable name are identified clearly within a data set's documentation files.


In contrast to sample weights, which adjust for Sampling Bias, attrition weights correct for bias introduced by attrition.
The objective of attrition weights is to render the Wave 2 sample comparable to the full Wave 1 sample. Mathematically, attrition weights are the inverse of the likelihood of being lost to attrition or dropping out: P (Wave 1) / (Wave 2)
Combination weights (also called longitudinal weights) adjust for both sampling bias and attrition bias. Mathematically, combination weights are the inverse of the likelihood of being sampled (i.e., the sample weight) multiplied by the inverse of the likelihood of being lost to attrition (i.e., the attrition weight): [P (target population) / P (sample)] x [P (Wave 1) / P (Wave 2)].
We suggest avoiding the use of attrition weights (either alone or as a part of combination weights) and instead of using full information maximum likelihood (FIML), or multiple imputation (MI) to adjust for attrition bias and then use the appropriate sample weight to adjust for sampling bias.
We make this recommendation because relative to FIML and MI, attrition weights (including combination weights) have two disadvantages:
Unlike FIML and MI, attrition weights often sharply reduce the analytical sample size and, thereby, statistical power. Typically, only those participants with data at every wave are assigned an attrition weight and used in subsequent analyses.
This problem is compounded as a study's number of waves (and therefore attrition) increases. Second, if many auxiliary variables (i.e., non-model variables related to missing data) are incorporated, FIML and MI may adjust for attrition bias more effectively than attrition weights.
Most statistical packages can use FIML, including STATA, SAS, Mplus, R, SPSS, and AMOS, and many use MI (e.g., STATA, SAS, Mplus, R, SPSS).


Most large-scale data sets were collected using complex sample designs that entail a clustered sampling design (e.g., schools are randomly sampled and then all students within the selected schools are sampled).
Because a clustered sampling design reduces variance (e.g., 100 students from the same school are likely more similar to one another demographically than are 100 students from 100 different schools), it also reduces standard errors and thereby inflates the change for Type I Errors.
To adjust for these design effects, a primary sampling unit variable (e.g., schools) and potentially a stratification variable are incorporated into analyses.
Most statistical packages (e.g., STATA, SAS, Mplus, R, SPSS) can adjust for a complex sampling design and typically the appropriate primary sampling unit and, if necessary, stratification variables are clearly identified within a data set's documentation files.
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Secondary Data Analysis/2. Research Questions and Research Ethics/Readings/@davis-keanAnsweringDevelopmentalQuestions2015.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: The Art of Data Science
item.description:
Bibliography:
Type: Journal Article
Title: The Art of Data Science,
Author: Peng, Roger D; Matsui, Elizabeth;
Year: 2018



Keywords: In Progress



The thinking begins before you even look at a dataset, and it's well worth devoting careful thought to your question. This point cannot be over-emphasized as many of the 'fatal' pitfalls of data analysis can be avoided by expending the mental energy to get your question right.


There are six basic types of questions.
Descriptive
Exploratory
Inferential
Predictive
Causal
Mechanistic
Understanding the type of question you are asking may be the most fundamental step you can take to ensure that, in the end, your interpretation of the results is correct.
The type of question you are asking directly informs how you interpret your results.
A descriptive question is one that seeks to summarize a characteristic of a set of data.
There is no interpretation of the result itself as the result is a fact, an attribute of the set of data that you are working with.
An exploratory question is one in which you analyze the data to see if there are patterns, trends, or relationships between variables.
These types of analyses are also called 'hypothesis-generating' analyses because rather than testing a hypothesis as would be done with an inferential, causal, or mechanistic question, you are looking for patterns that would support proposing a hypothesis.
An inferential question would be a restatement of this proposed hypothesis as a question and would be answered by analyzing a different set of data.
A predictive question would be one where you ask what types of people will eat a diet high in fresh fruits and vegetables during the next year. In this type of question you are less interested in what causes someone to eat a certain diet, just what predicts whether someone will eat this certain diet.
A causal question asks about whether changing one factor will change another factor, on average, in a population.
Sometimes the underlying design of the data collection, by default, allows for the question that you ask to be causal.
In other instances, even if your data are not from a randomized trial, you can take an analytic approach designed to answer a causal question.
A question that asks how a diet high in fresh fruits and vegetables leads to a reduction in the number of viral illnesses would be a mechanistic question.
By necessity, many data analyses answer multiple types of questions.
If a data analysis aims to answer an inferential question, descriptive and exploratory questions must also be answered during the process of answering the inferential question.
The type of question you ask is determined in part by the data available to you (unless you plan to conduct a study and collect the data needed to do the analysis).
If this type of data set does not exist, then the best you may be able to do is either apply causal analysis methods to observational data or instead answer an inferential question about diet and viral illness.


Establish your expectations about the question
Gathering information about your question
Determining if your expectations match the information you gathered, and then refining your question (or expectations) if your expectations did not match the information you gathered.


There are five key characteristics of a good question for a data analysis, which range from the very basic characteristic that the question should not have already been answered to the more abstract characteristic that each of the possible answers to the question should have a single interpretation and be meaningful.
The question should be of interest to your audience, the identity of which will depend on the context and environment in which you are working with data.
You should also check that the question has not already been answered. With the recent explosion of data, the growing amount of publicly available data, and the seemingly endless scientific literature and other resources, it is not uncommon to discover that your question of interest has been answered already.
The question should also stem from a plausible framework.
If you ask a question whose framework is not plausible, you are likely to end up with an answer that's difficult to interpret or have confidence in.
Many questions are raised about the result itself: is it really correct?, why are these things correlated- is there another explanation?, and others. You can ensure that your question is grounded in a plausible framework by using your own knowledge of the subject area and doing a little research, which together can go a long way in terms of helping you sort out whether your question is grounded in a plausible framework.
The question, should also, of course, be answerable.
Specificity is also an important characteristic of a good question.
Working towards specificity will refine your question and directly inform what steps to take when you start looking at data.
With this degree of specificity, your plan of attack is much clearer and the answer you will get at the end of the data analysis will be more interpretable as you will either recommend or not recommend the specific action.


Another aspect to consider when you’re developing your question is what will happen when you translate it into a data problem. Every question must be operationalized as a data analysis that leads to a result.
Pausing to think through what the results of the data analysis would look like and how they might be interpreted is important as it can prevent you from wasting a lot of time embarking on an analysis whose result is not interpretable.
The typical type of question that does not meet this criterion is a question that uses inappropriate data.
The problem with this question is that for a single possible answer, there are multiple interpretations. This scenario of multiple interpretations arises when at least one of the variables you use is not a good measure of the concept you are truly after.
To head off this problem, you will want to make sure that the data available to answer your question provide reasonably specific measures of the factors required to answer your question.
A related problem that intergeres with interpretation of results is confounding.
Confounding is a potential problem when your question asks about the relationship between factors.
A brief description of the concept of confounding is that it is present when a factor that you were not necessarily considering in your question is related to both your exposure of interest and your outcome of interest.
As you refine your question, spend time identifying the potential confounders and thinking about whether your dataset includes information about these potential confounders.
Another type of problem that can occur when inappropriate data are used is that the result is not interpretable because the underlying way in which the data were collected lead to a biased result.
The other major bias to understand and consider when refining your question is selection bias, which occurs when the data your are analyzing were collected in such a way to inflate the proportion of people who have both characteristics above what exists in the general population.
A good rule of thumb is that if you are examining relationships between two factors, bias may be a problem if you are more (or less) likely to observe individuals with both factors because of how the population was selected, or how a person might recall the past when responding to a survey.
The best time to consider its effects on your data analysis is when you are identifying the question you will answer and thinking about how you are going to answer the question with the data available to you.
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Secondary Data Analysis/2. Research Questions and Research Ethics/Readings/@pengArtDataScience2018.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: The importance of stupidity in scientific research
item.description:
Bibliography: Schwartz, M. A. (2008). The importance of stupidity in scientific research. Journal of Cell Science, 121(11), 1771–1771. https://doi.org/10.1242/jcs.033340
Type: Journal Article
Title: The importance of stupidity in scientific research,
Author: Schwartz, Martin A.;
Journal: Journal of Cell Science,
Volume: 121,
Issue: 11
Pages: 1771-1771
Year: 2008
DOI: 10.1242/jcs.033340
ISSN: 1477-9137, 0021-9533


Keywords: Read



Science makes me feel stupid too. It's just that I've gotten used to it. So used to it, in fact, that I actively seek out new opportunities to feel stupid. I wouldn't know what to do without that feeling. I even think it's supposed to be this way.
Henry Taube (who won the Novel Prize two years later) told me he didn't know how to solve the problem I was having in his area. I was a third-year graduate student and I figured that Taube knew about 1000 times more than I did (conservative estimate). If he didn't have the answer, nobody did.
That's when it hit me: nobody did. That's why it was a research problem. And being my research problem, it was up to me to solve.
The crucial lesson was that the scope of things I did not know was, for all practical purposes, infinite. That realization, instead of being discouraging, was liberating. If our ignorance is infinite, the only possible course of action is to muddle through as best we can.
We just don't know what we're doing. We can't be sure whether we're asking the right answer or doing the right experiment until we get the answer or the result.
Doing significant research is intrinsically hard and changing departmental, institutional or national policies will not succeed in lessening its intrinsic difficulty.
We don't do a good enough job of teaching our students how to be productively stupid - that is, if we don't feel stupid it means we're not really trying.
Science involves confronting our 'absolute stupidity.' that kind of stupidity is an existential fact, inherent in our efforts to push our way into the unknown.
Preliminary and thesis exams have the right idea when the faculty committee pushes until the student starts getting the answers wrong or gives up and says, ‘I don’t know’. The point of the exam isn’t to see if the student gets all the answers right. If they do, it’s the faculty who failed the exam. The point is to identify the student’s weaknesses, partly to see where they need to invest some effort and partly to see whether the student’s knowledge fails at a sufficiently high level that they are ready to take on a research project.
Productive stupidity means being ignorant by choice.
The more comfortable we become with being stupid, the deeper we will wade into the unknown and the more likely we are to make big discoveries.
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Secondary Data Analysis/2. Research Questions and Research Ethics/Readings/@schwartzImportanceStupidityScientific2008.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 2. Research Questions and Research Ethics
item.description:
Read @schwartzImportanceStupidityScientific2008
Read @pengArtDataScience2018
Read @davis-keanAnsweringDevelopmentalQuestions2015


Before you put pen to paper (or analyze data), formulate a research question.
A research question is a statement that identifies the phenomenon to be studied.
For example, "Does preschool influence children's language skills?"
Why are good research questions important and what makes them 'good?'
Purpose
Relevance
Feasibility



To produce a research question, you need to know the literature first.
Find out what has been done and how you can contribute to the existing literature.


I have a research question.
If you do not have a research question, narrow down your topic.
Review the literature
Is the question viable, original. feasible?
You have a research question!


Narrow down on an area of interest
Within that area, try to answer a question that:
Has either not been addressed before
Has been addressed before but that you could extend (i.e., new data-set, different approach, etc.)
Has been addressed but requires replication
Starts a new research area (NOT recommended)


Read as much as you can on the topic
Read recent studies first, then read backwards
Read all relevant papers (or at least the influential ones)
Ideas on the research topic often come from reading
The more you read, the easier it will be to come up with research questions


Reviewing the literature will allow you to understand whether your question has been answered/is valid.
By reading previous studies, you might get ideas on how to tweak your original research question into a new one.
Whether you have or do not have a research question, it is crucial that you review the literature in the area first.
Many leave the review as the last step, but this is dangerous.



Not original
Not feasible
Time constraint (e.g., not enough time)
Resources (e.g., lack of data)
Knowledge (e.g., do I know method X?)
Too broadly defined research question
Not well justified
Not motivated by literature


Start searching for a topic as early as possible
Once you narrow down a topic/area, look at the relevant literature (i.e., a literature review)
Once you have done the literature review (has it already been done? No, why not? Is it interesting/relevant?), then ask yourself:
Is the question specific (not too broad)?
Is it feasible in the allotted time?
Do I have enough resources (data) to answer this question?
How about knowledge (methods)?
Is the research question falling within my area of research?
If the answer is yes to all the previous question, congratulations, you have a research question.
Your time is your most important resource.
Do not take a project that you will lead if it only leads to one paper (except for in very rare circumstances)
Try to commit to doing 3 papers on a topic/data set
More efficient time use (e.g., read similar lit)
Looks good when others are evaluating your CV
A good research question will
Allow outsiders to see your intentions
Help you develop hypotheses (not always)
Contributes to existing knowledge
Contribution does not have to be huge
Replication is a contribution
Filling a gap is not enough justification, why does this gap matter?
Guide the design of your methods
Allow the target population to be identified
Identify the outcome variables and key predictors of those variables
Determine what type of study is needed (e.g., descriptive, correlational, experimental)
Identify background characteristics that might influence predictors and outcomes
Raise questions about how to best collect data
Influence the number of participants in the study
Writing a good question is an iterative process
What do you want to learn about?
Draft and redraft with increasing specificity using the guidelines listed above.
Ask for feedback from colleagues (science is a collective effort).
Build on the work of others by conducting a systematic literature review.


This is a key writing skill that you will need to do for every paper you write.
Hook the reader in.
Practice!


Explain the larger context that this study will inform.
Start big and then work down to the end of the paragraph to set up something more specific that is important to know.


Flows directly from the earlier points in paragraph 1. If studying X is important, then here is what I am doing.
State the basic aims, hypotheses, questions, and give the briefest overview of the data and methods (focusing on strengths)


Explain the potential impact of the specific things you lay out in the prior paragraph - could be theoretically, in terms of policy, filling holes, etc.
Can be combined with paragraph 2 in some cases.


"The scientific literature is our institutional memory. It is important that this literature accurately reflect what happened, who did it, and to what extend one observation is independent of another." - Dennis McInerney


Double Publication involves publishing the same data more than once.
Piecemeal Publication involves dividing the report of a research project into multiple articles.
The articles cannot be integrated into one
Each article has a distinct purpose
Duplicate and piecemeal publications are misleading and distort the scientific literature.
Publication ethics disallow duplicate publication (Publication Ethics: Plagiarism, Self-Plagiarism, Duplicate Publication, and Piecemeal Publication - Julia Muennich Cowell, 2017)


A researcher was interested in changes in marital quality and recruited a sample of newlywed couples and annually collected data from them over five years. The main question of interest was the extent to which personality traits at the time of marriage predict marital satisfaction and marital commitment post marriage. The researcher wrote two papers. One focused on the prediction of marital satisfaction, and the other focused on the prediction of marital commitment. The design of the study was he same in each paper, with the exception of the change in outcomes.
Piecemeal
A researcher recruited newlyweds and planned annual assessments over a five years. Some measures were assessments over a five years. Some measures were common to each annual assessment, whereas others common to each annual assessment, whereas others were not. After the first wave of data collection, she wrote were not. After the first wave of data collection, she wrote an article regarding the relation between divorce history an article regarding the relation between divorce history and marital satisfaction. After three waves of data and marital satisfaction. After three waves of data collection, she wrote an article on how couples who made collection, she wrote an article on how couples who made the transition to parenthood differed in changes in marital the transition to parenthood differed in changes in marital satisfaction from those who did not experience the satisfaction from those who did not experience the transition. After five waves of data collection, she wrote a transition. After five waves of data collection, she wrote a third article on the predictors of marital dissolution. The third article on the predictors of marital dissolution. The researcher decided to publish these as three separate researcher decided to publish these as three separate articles.
Not Piecemeal
Researcher B was interested in the relation between family process and adolescent adjustment. She conducted and published a study in which the main conducted and published a study in which the main objective was to identify specific family processes that objective was to identify specific family processes that mediated the relation between family structure and mediated the relation between family structure and adjustment. Later, she read a new study that proposed that two of the family processes that she studied had an interactive effect on adjustment. Although such an interactive effect was not of interest in the original study, interactive effect was not of interest in the original study, in additional analyses she found that such an effect did occur in her sample, although in a slightly different than in the newly published article. She wrote a second article to address this issue.
Not Piecemeal
A researcher was interested in the extent to which support for marriage from family and friends affects rating of relationship quality. He collected data from a large convenience sample. Although not planned, the sample contained about 60% of persons in their first marriages and 40% of persons in remarriages. The researcher prepared two papers that examined the question of interest. In the first paper, he used data from the first-marriage subjects, whereas in the second paper he used data from the remarried subjects. The variables assessed and reported in the two papers were the same.
Piecemeal
A researcher was interested in the links between family structure and child adjustment. The researcher administered a survey to high school students. She discovered that there were large numbers in two-biological parent, single divorced mother, and stepfather families, but very few students were in the single divorced father and stepmother families as part of the survey, students in stepfamilies answered survey items regarding the parenting behaviors of their stepparents as well as of their parents. She wrote two papers. The first examined differences in adjustment in children from two-biological parent, single divorced mother, and stepfather families (the groups with the largest sample sizes). To facilitate the interpretation of family structure effects, she decided to exclude the rather small number of students in the second paper, she explored whether children's adjustment was related to how they rated the parenting behaviors of their parents and stepparents.
Not Piecemeal
A researcher was interested in rates of divorce in first-marriages and remarriages in different countries. She obtained data from an international organization that contained information on a number of different countries and wrote two papers. The first addressed the divorce rates in these two kinds of couples in Canada, and the second dealt with the same issue in England. The same theoretical rationale and measures were used in both papers, although the results led to different conclusions.
Piecemeal
Focus on quality and not quantity of publications


Replicate the study with a different sample, setting, or methodology.
Do this if most of the past research you have read examines one type of sample, setting, or method.
Examine the topic using a different design. If the study was a quasi- or non-experimental, conduct an experiment.
Do this if causation has not been consistently established by past research, or it has not been consistently established with the population you are interested in.
Examine how another variable might impact results
Do this if you have research evidence to suggest that results may depend on another variable.
Conduct a similar study with a different outcome or dependent variable.
Do this if you find research evidence supporting the new associations you plan to examine.


Being first is not always a sign of being a good scientist
Many discoveries are wrong or over claimed.


You do not show you are a great scientist by being the first to claim something.
A large part of getting over being scooped is getting over yourself and realizing that science is bigger than any one of us.
It also means you are doing something other people care about.
If you are scooped, do not be discouraged. It is unlikely that any two researchers would address a question in the exact same way.
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Secondary Data Analysis/2. Research Questions and Research Ethics/2. Research Questions and Research Ethics.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 3. Sharing and Accessing Secondary Data
item.description:
Reinforces open science = science works most effectively
Encourages diversity of analysis and opinions
Promotes new research and/or new methods
Improves methods of data collection and measurement
Reduces costs by avoiding duplicate data collection efforts and enhance the impact of the project



Of 116 articles, 64 did not have a full correlation matrix.
We sent 64 emails and only 16 responded.
Of the 16 that responded, only 9 sent us information (15% response)
In biology, they found that for each year that passes, the odds of an email address not working are 7% higher





The FAIR Guiding Principles for scientific data management and stewardship

How will people find your data? (repository; meta data; etc.)
How will people access your data (restricted/public? When will it be made available? Etc.)
Are there barriers to using your data? (formats, methods, documentation?)
Is it easy for people to re-use your data? (assure high quality, how will it be stored long-term?)



University repository
Generalist data repository
Discipline specific data repository
Government or agency data portals
Other platforms designed for sharing: OSF.


Supplementary materials
University staff profile
Personal website
Project website
Government agency websites


Informal networks
On request
Commercial datasets (unless you have access through a library, department, funding)



Publicly available (i.e., de-identified)
Restricted access (i.e., request to use)
Unshareable (i.e., no sharing possible)


All verifiable/reusable data possibly through anonymization
Aggregated/summarized/redacted version of the data
Publicly share some parts and restrict access to others
Restrict access, but share details of data held
Share only details about study, no sharing possible


Many datasets have both public and restricted files.
Restricted data contains more data and a wider range of data values than are included in public use data.
For most, the public-use files provide all the data they will need for most analyses, though some users may find that only the restricted files have the specific data they need.
If you are not sure, first examine the public-use data.
Outliers (unusually high or unusually low values) are top- or bottom-coded to prevent identification of unique schools, teachers, parents, and children without affecting overall data quality.
Some continuous variables are converted into categorical variables, and some categorical variables have their categories collapsed.
Category value labels are provided for continuous variables that are converted into categorical variables.
Variables with too few cases and/or a sparse distribution are suppressed. The values for these variables are set to -2 and labelled 'suppressed' in the Electronic Codebook (ECB). The value -2 means that the data for this variable are suppressed to protect the respondent's confidentiality.
Variables that provide a particularly identifying characteristic, such as a specific disability, or information that could be matched against external data sources to obtain a specific identifying characteristic, such as exact date of marriage or divorce, are also suppressed. The values for these variables are set to -2.


Will vary for different data, but for all, you will need to complete an application.
Submit signed license document
Primary researcher
Senior official at institution
Submit signed and notarized affidavits of nondisclosure for all proposed users.
Submit a signed security plan (must specify the exact locked location) where the data will be secured. You cannot transmit restricted-use data.
Maintain a data license file and ensure that all authorized users follow the agreed upon terms.
Participate in unannounced security inspections to ensure compliance.
Adhere to established publication rules.
Submit all materials for disclosure review.
Complete annual trainings online.
Complete yearly reports of what work you have done.



Start with a broad question.
Think about who might collect that data (e.g., governments, other researchers, etc.)
Want to stick close to a specific subfield or type of data?
Look for recognized repositories in your field, large research projects, or publications that have data access statements.
Likely need to combine several search strategies.
Remember
Some disciplines have more of a tradition of sharing
Non-sensitive data are easier to obtain than sensitive data

Also check: https://osf.io and ldbase.org


Archives are easily searchable
Searching by study topic is helpful when you are looking for studies focused on a specific subject.
Searching by variable name is helpful when you are interested in a particular variable (e.g., spanking).
Often, studies are organized into collections in each archive so a researcher can quickly identify groups of studies focused on a particular subarea.
The organization of each archive varies, but most share several major features.
Most archives allow you to perform basic descriptive analyses before the downloading a dataset.
This is great because you can determine whether a variable of interest has a large enough sample size, enough variance in repsonses, for your purposes.
Such online analyses are also useful for testing a new hypothesis before collecting new data on the topic or performing preliminary analyses for grant applications.
Most archives offer FAQs, tips for effective searching, and access to staff members via email.
ICPSR tutorial
How to search for variables and filter
How to search for publications
How to look at descriptive within and across studies
How to look for studies and variables within studies
Study usage reports


Subject Matter
Consider whether the subject is consistent with your problem definition and whether the data apply to the time/population of interest
Methods
Consider whether the data can be used with your preferred method of analysis or if you'll need ot learn a new skill.
Measurement
Determine whether the data capture the measures and constructs you are interested in with sufficient/adequate detail.
Time
You will save time on data collection and get access to larger scale data, but may spend more time on cleaning, modifying, getting documentation, etc.
License/Copyright
Is the data licensed? Does it restrict usage?
Terms of Use
Are the terms you need to meet to gain access to the data or other restrictions?
Citations
You will want to formally cite the data you use; data sets should have a persistent identifier to help cite the data, such as DOI.
Documentation
Look for good documentation on how the data was collected, for what purpose, how it was transformed.
Credibility
Is the data from a recognized lab, researcher, institution? Do the publications based on the data hold?



Does the dataset contain the information you require to answer your research question(s) and meet your objectives?
Do the measures used match those you require?
Is the data set a proxy for the data you really need?
Does the dataset cover the population that is the subject of your research?
Does the dataset cover the geographical area that is the subject of your research?
Can data about the population that is the subject of your research be separated from unwanted data?
Are the data for the right time period or sufficiently up to date?
Are data available for all the variables you require to answer your research question(s) and meet your objectives?
Are the variables defined clearly?


How reliable is the dataset?
How credible is the data source?
Is it clear what the source of the data is?
Do the credentials of the source of the data (author, institution, or organization sponsoring the data) suggest it is likely to be reliable?
Do the data have an associated copyright statement?
Do associated published documents exist?
Does the source contain contact details for obtaining further information about the data?
Is the method described clearly?
If sampling was used, what was the procedure and what were the associated sampling errors and response rates?
Who was responsible for collecting or recording the data?
(For surveys) Is a copy of the questionnaire or interview checklist included?
(For compiled data) Are you clear how the data were analyzed and compiled?
Are the data likely to contain measurement bias?
What was the original purpose for which the data were collected?
Who was the target


The most important step is to read ALL the data documentation.


Before assessing data, review codebooks and questionnaires
What information was collected
For whom and when and where
What changes were made before archiving
Codebooks also include other information (e.g., topics addressed, questions and measurements used, frequency of responses or values, how to use the data, etc.)
Like a regular book, some codebooks are better than others.
If people code the variable in a certain way, is there potential for error? Would two researchers get the same outcomes if they chose to code the variable differently?
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Secondary Data Analysis/3. Sharing and Accessing Secondary Data/3. Sharing and Accessing Secondary Data.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 4. STATA Basics and Data Management
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Secondary Data Analysis/4. STATA Basics and Data Management/4. STATA Basics and Data Management.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 5. STATA Basics and Data Management
item.description:
Great for data management
Very powerful and flexible, for most models.
STATA can
Handle Continuous, Categorical, and count variables
Evaluate group differences via multiple group analysis
Evaluate complex survey data and make necessary adjustments (e.g., clustering, weights)
Handle missing data through full information maximum likelihood or multiple imputations
Run more basic (Regression, EFA, CFA) and more complex analyses (MLM, LGCM, GMM)




The big window
Results of all STATA commands appear here (except graphs)


Records all STATA commands that have been entered. A previous command can be repeated by double-clicking the command in the Review window


Shows a record of all variables in the dataset


Across the top of the screen


Click the (editor) button. All data are visible here.
Note that no commands can be executed when the data editor is open.


There are two ways to operate STATA


Commands can be types directly into the Command window and executed by pressing Enter.


Commands can be written in a separate file (called a do-file) and executed together in one step.


List of all the commands you need for your project
No need to repeat work; recreate your dataset by running the do-file
Easy to correct mistakes you find later
To create / edit do-file:
Starting a new do-file: doedit
Editing an existing do-file: doedit DOFILENAME.do
Type in commands
Save do-file (control + s)
To use
Do DOFILENAME.Do
Try to be organized
Use headings
For all test in do-flies that are not commands, begin the line with *


Log records all commands and output during the session
To use:
Open new log
Log using LOGNAME.log / cmdlog using CLOGNAME.log
Write over an existing log
Log using LOGNAME.log / cmdlog using CMDLOGNAME.log, replace
Add to an existing log
Log using LOGNAME.log / cmdlog using CMDLOGNAME.log, append
To close log
Log close / cmdlog close


To read a file using the command window
Use "C:...\sample.dta", clear use sample.dta, clear
To save a file
Save "C:...\sample.dta" [, replace]



Type 'browse' in the command window
Column holds the variable
Row holds the observation
Cell of a particular variable for a particular observation is a value


Allows you to edit the data


The number of observations in the dataset
Number of variables in the dataset
The amount of memory the dataset is using and how much memory you still have to work with
Basic information about the variables in our dataset



Variable name, label and type
Some basic descriptive statistics for variable



The general syntax for all STATA commands is:
[prefix:] cmdname [varlist] [=exp] [if exp] [in exp] [weight] [using filename] [, options]
Elements in square brackets are optional for some commands
Sometimes cmdname is all that is required, for example, codebook or describe
STATA is case sensitive



New variables can be created using generate
Gen racev2 = race
New variable can contain functions or combinations of existing variables
Gen income = inc1 + inc2 + inc3
You can use *, +, -, /, ^
Replace may be used to change the contents of an existing variable
Replace oldvar = exp1 [if exp2]
Always recommend that you do not save over original values.
'If' is used to restrict the command to a desired subset of observations:
Replace race =. If race == 999
The double == sign is used to test for equality, while the single sign is used for assignment
Operators can be used after if:
& denotes 'and'
| denotes 'or'
~ or ! Denote 'not'
Rename may be used to rename variables
Rename oldvarname newvarname
To drop a variable or variables, type
Drop varlist
Alternatively, keep varlist eliminates everything but varlist
To drop certain observations, use
Drop if exp
For example, drop if unemplrate==


Dataset in memory is called 'master dataset'
Dataset filename is called 'using dataset'
Variables with same name will be combined
Variables in only one dataset will have missing values for observations from the other dataset.
To join corresponding observations from a STATA dataset with those in the dataset in memory, type:
Merge 1:1 varlist using filename

If more than one observations has the same value of varlist in the master dataset, use:
Merge m: 1 varlist using filename
To add another STATA dataset below the end of the dataset in memory, type:
Append using filename



For Mean, Standard Deviation (SD) use sum:
Sum bex_tm54
For stats by subgroup, add bysort: in option section
Bysort csex_m01: sum bex_tm54
For Categorical Variable s use tab:
Tab csex_m01


Syntax using correlate
Correlate bex_tm54 bex_tm1s bex_tmg3

pwcorr provides significance levels



Syntax using ttest
ttest bex_tm54, by (csex_m01)


Results using regress:
Regress bex_tm 54 meducm 01 inc_6_54 csex_m01

Coef. = Beta Coefficient
Std. Err. = Standard error
T = Ratio of beta to standard error
P>|t| = significance level
[95% conf. Interval] = Confidence Interval
Critial Ratio
The most basic form of a statistical test of significance
1.96 for p < .05
2.58 for p < .01
3.24 for p < .001


If you know the name of a command, enter
Help cmdname
If you don't know it, enter
Findit word 1 [word2] ...
This queries a database and some of the official internet sources (such as STATA FAQs, STATA articles)
Google
Email or call STATA Technical services
Statalist archives / forums
Check the cheat sheets (statacheatsheets.pdf)
item.guid: University Resources/Current/Secondary Data Analysis/5. STATA Basics and Data Management/5. STATA Basics and Data Management.md
item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: Variable Selection & Data Relationships
item.description:
Big data allows for complex analyses and many (undocumented) decisions are made during the research project, including what IV, DV, and covariates to include.




https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/p-hacking/



What are covariates and why do we include them?
Conditioning on such risk factors is necessary to remove bias.
Do NOT use p-values to determine covariate inclusion. Use a priori theory!
Achieving statistical significance with covariates and without transparency



As you are making decisions regarding your variables, consider the following questions:
How will constructs be operationalized?
What items will be used and which measures are critical to the tests?
If multiple measures are available, what will be done?
These issues often require quite a bit of conceptual considerations and defending in the peer-review process.


In big datasets, measures are often abbreviated.
Measurement problems arise when
The concept to be measured are vague or poorly defined
Indicators are imperfect measures of the underlying construct
Individual responses are inaccurate (e.g., distraction, illness, poor comprehension)
Errors lead to erroneous values
Accuracy
The closeness of the measurement to the true value
Bias
A systematic variation of measurements from the quality being measured
Precision
The closeness of repeated measurements to one another



Inaccurate and unreliable measurement results in serious concerns regarding the Validity and Reliability of the hypotheses tested using given measures.

The vast majority of constructs require more than one item, Why?
Low content validity (sensitivity and reliability)


The primary objective of creating a series of composite scales is to avoid the exclusive use of, or dependence on, single item constructs where possible.
The use of several variables as indicators provides an opportunity to represent differing facets of a given concept, with the aim of yielding a more well-rounded perspective and, arguably, a better measure.

X1 = I often feel alone
X2 = I am often sad
X3 = I often feel like crying
X4 = I cannot shake off the blues
alpha X1 X2 X3 X4, std item
alpha X1 X2 X3 X4, std gen (depress)
alpha X1 X2 X3 X4, std (depress) min(3)


Cronbach's Alpha (One metric of reliability)
- 0.90 or greater = great
- 0.80 - 0.89 = good
- 0.70 - 0.79 = acceptable
- 0.60 - 0.69 = marginal
- 0.59 or less = not acceptable
sem (Depress-> X1, ) (Depress-> X2, ) (Depress-> X3, ) (Depress-> X4, ) standardized latent(Depress ) nocapslatent (CFA code)
factor x1 x2 x3 x4 (EFA code)

Alpha approach takes the average, whereas factor approach allows different weighting of items.

Bwt_tm 5 - bag_tmx 5, as well as column wjpvwcx 5 - wjpcwcx 5 Convergent Validity
(wjpvwcx 5, bag_tmx 5) Discriminant Validity
Within indicator correlations should exceed 0.50.



Always look at your data
Data collection issues: recording errors
~60 different ways of spelling Philadelphia in one dataset
browse (stata syntax)
sum (Continuous variables)
tab (Categorical Variable)



http://guessthecorrelation.com/​
Guess that correlation is a game with a purpose. It is entertaining, but data on our guesses are collected and used to analyze how we perceive correlations in scatterplots. So, the more people that play, the more data generated.
Always plot your data.


Outliers are anomalous objects or values
Data that have characteristics different from most others
Values of an attribute that are unusual
This is not just noise! An outlier is an event that is suspected of not being generated by the same mechanisms as the rest of the data.



Deviates significantly from the rest of the dataset


Deviates significantly with respect to a specific context of the object


The individual data objects may not be outliers, but the object as a whole deviate significantly from the entire dataset.



Departures from normality are usually not serious in large samples, but there may be some bias in standard errors and test statistics.
One solution is to transform the non-normal data (e.g., log, square root, etc.)
Other methods are potentially more rigorous


Estimates of standard errors are robust against non-normality because assumptions of Normality are relaxed.
Several different ways to get robust standard errors.
Huber-White sandwich method, use the option vce (robust)







Why do we test for reliability in subpopulations?
Establish the psychometric properties of a new or existing measure/assessment tool
Means for determining generalizeability
Are we measuring the same construct in the same way across groups or across time?
Increase confidence that observed differences between groups reflect true differences and not those ties to measurement.
Reliability within subgroups is often assumed but rarely tested and is a big issue for many datasets that do not use previously validated meaures.


Why use existing composites?
Data availability: you often may not have all necessary data to create the composite
Reproducibility: everyone uses the same construct
Convenience: time and effort spent on identifying possible composites and determining best source of information to creating them
But first, always read the user's guide and when item level data are available, check yourself!

item.dc:creator: Millie

item.title: 7. Sampling & Complex Designs
item.description:
Why should we strive for population representative sampling?
Important for policy or practice. We do not want to recommend changes that are not based on research that is representative of the full population those changes would impact.
How?
Narrow our populations of interest (e.g., Columbus instead of the US)
Work on large teams
Use secondary data


Normally used to compensate for over- and under-sampling of individuals
Example
It is common to over-sample minority groups... If we doubled the size of our minority sample, then each minority case would get a design weight of 1/2 or .5.
We use the design weight when we want the statistics to be representative of the population.


Used to compensate for the fact that persons with certain characteristics are not as likely to respond to the survey.
Example
Most population surveys have substantially more female than male respondents; because surveys over-represents females and under-represents males in the population, a weight is used to compensate for this bias.
There are many responsent characteristics that are likely to be related to the propensity to respond such as age, education, race/ethnicity, place of residence.



Dataset with cases
Simple mean
(4 + 2 + 1 + 5 + 2) / 5 = 2.8
Weighted mean
{(4 1) + (2 2) + (1 4) + (5 1) + (2 * 2)} / 10 = 2.1


With unweighted data, each case is counted equally
With weighted data, each case is counted relative to its representation in the population
Unweighted data represent only those in the sample who provide data
Weights allow analyses that represent the target population



Most STATA commands can deal with weighted data, where the weight is a variable in the dataset.
You need to specify the type of weight and the weight variable, using brackets at the end of your command, as in:
summarize x [weight=weightvarname]
tab x [weight=weightvarname]
regress y x [weight=weightvarname]
There are 4 types of weights in STATA, but for most data analyses you will use one of the following:
Probability pweights, for observations sampled with unequal probability of selection. Use this for inferential analyses.
Analytic aweights, for data containing averages where the average is weighted by the # obs used in calculating the average…. Use this for your descriptive statistics.




Different studies create different types of weights... Some data create weights depending on:
Level of analysis (child, teacher, or school)
Type of analysis (cross-sectional vs. Longitudinal)
Source of data (child assessment, parent interview, teacher questionnaires, etc.)
For example, the ECLS-K has ~ 105 different options


Many suggest you use combination weights when estimating longitudinal analyses because they assume that these users will not adjust for attrition on their own.
I suggest avoiding the use of attrition weights.
Instead, use modern missing data procedures for attrition bias, and use the appropriate sample weight to adjust for sampling bias
I make this recommendation because attrition weights have two key disadvantages
Attrition weights often reduce the analytical sample size, and thereby, statistical power.
If many non-model variables related to missing data are incorporated, missing data techniques adjust for attrition bias more effectively than attrition weights


Use weights whenever possible, but some methods do not allow weights
Steps to follow to avoid vias in unweighted analyses
Include as Independent Variable that might account for the sample design or non-response
If a weight is available, it can also be included as an IV
If the weight is associated with the outcom ein a model including the design variables, then the weight is likely to have been constructed in a way related to your outcome; bias is possile.
E.g., some multilevel models, some structural equation programs, etc.


National samples are first divided into primary sampling units... What these units are depends on the study.
- E.g., in many data of the US the PSUs are geographic areas consisting of counties or groups of counties



After identifying PSUs, then PSUs are stratified into groups.
These groups are formed to keep similar units together... How many and what types of strata are determined by study goals.

Then within each strata, and within PSUs, you sample


Software can make the adjustment... A few different approaches with the easiest being the Taylor Series approach
Use primary sampling unit (PSU) and strata variables in the data file.
The strata and PSU identifiers are often associated with a specific sampling weight variable.
For example, in the ECLS-K the weight C1CW0 has the following strata and PSU: C1TVWSTR and C1TCWPSU

svyset PSU [pweight = WEIGHT], strata(STRATA)

Then use svy: before your subsequent commands (e.g., svy: tab or svy: mean or svy: regress)
svy: will NOT work with all commands
svy: mean and mean [weight = weight] yield the same mean estimates… it is the SEs that are different)




Weights should be used when analyzing data from national samples; otherwise, you cannot make claims about representativeness
The appropriate weight should be selected based on:
Level of analysis
Round (s) of data
Source (s) of data
There may not be a 'perfect' weight for many analyses
All statistical tests should be based on standard errors that account for complex sample design

item.title: Assignment 4
item.description:
This classwork/homework assignment is a multiple imputation activity. You will continue to use data from the Early Childhood Longitudinal Study-Kindergarten 2011 Cohort. The classwork/homework write-up is due by Tuesday at 11:59PM (3/18). The data you need come from two sources. The first is the data file you have been working on for class activities the last several week. The second is located in this week's folder.
A researcher wants to know whether maternal depressive symptoms are associated with children’s early learning and development. But before the researcher can address this question, you are asked to think about and address missing data. The researcher has provided you with several variables in addition to the variables you have worked with thus far:

You are asked to include an overall composite of depressive symptoms. The research provides you with 12 items that you are asked to composite (P2BOTHER P2APPETI P2BLUE P2KPMIND P2DEPRES P2EFFORT P2FEARFL P2RESTLS P2TALKLS P2LONELY P2SAD P2NOTGO).
You will also include three child variables: a) a variable capturing children’s academic achievement, b) a variable capturing children’s socioemotional skills, and c) a variable capturing children’s executive functioning. For the academic achievement measure, you will need to create a new composite variable that is composed of reading, math, and science (X2RSCALK4 X2MSCALK4 X2SSCALK4). For socioemotional skills, you will need to create a new variable that is the average of teacher reports of self-control, interpersonal skills, externalizing behavior, and internalizing behavior (i.e., X2TCHINT X2TCHEXT X2TCHCON X2TCHPER). Children’s executive functioning skills are captured with a single item: X2DCCSTOT.
The researcher also wants you to include covariates/indicators for race/ethnicity (X_RACETH_R), child sex (X_CHSEX_R), income (X2INCCAT_I), parents’ marital status (P1CURMAR), parents physical health (P2HEALTH), household members under 18 (X1LESS18), and household members over 18 (X1OVER18) .
With that in mind...
Step 1: You need to merge the new data into the dataset you have been working with. This requires a 1 to 1 merge using CHILDID. This step will be graded via your do/log files (.25 points)
Step 2: Once the data are merged, examine your data. Orient yourself to the old and new variables (e.g., are they continuous, categorical etc etc) and recode any new variables as appropriate. Recall how Stata recognizes missing data. Please also create the appropriate composites prior to imputation. The composites will be what you will use in your imputation. If you recode other variables, please provide a justification. This step will be graded via your do/log files and your justification in your word document. (.25 points)
Step 3: Once you have cleaned your data, run some descriptives for all of your variables (including your covariates) and determine the degree of missing values for each variable. Please also estimate a correlation matrix for your focal independent and dependent variables (do not include the list of covariates for your correlation matrix). What  patterns you notice from the descriptive statistics? How much missing data are there for the variables? What patterns do you notice from the correlation matrix? (1.00 point)
Step 4: Determine whether data are MCAR. Examine and discuss the missing data patterns. Are there common patterns of missing data? Are there uncommon patterns of missing data? Anything you notice worth discussing? If data are not MCAR, discuss whether the data may meet assumptions of MAR or MNAR. Why or why not? If you have any concerns proceeding to imputation, discuss it here. (1.25 points)
Step 5: Run an imputation model with 10 datasets. Make sure you specify each variable correctly. And remember to upload your do and log files (for the entire assignment). This step will be graded via your do file (1.00 point)
Step 6: After you have run your imputation, estimate descriptives within the 10 imputed datasets. You do not have to do this for every variable. Run these descriptives for the focal variables of interest (depressive symptoms, children's academic achievement, social skills, and executive functioning). Use the mi xeq command (e.g., mi xeq: sum XYZ). Discuss what you notice about the means/SDs across the imputations. (1.00 point)
Step 7. Estimate correlations (use mi xeq: corr) among your focal variables from step 1, but this time within your 10 datasets. Are there any similarities between the imputed and non-imputed data? Are there any other differences you notice? (.75 points)
Step 8. Upload your word document, log file, and do file. Please upload stata versions of your log/do files (not copied/pasted into word).
